lead_paragraph: Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of the Portuguese energy company Galp Energia, the latest move in a global expansion by Sinopec, China’s largest oil refiner. Under the terms of the deal, the state-owned Sinopec will invest $4.8 billion for a 30 percent stake in Petrogal Brasil, a subsidiary of Galp Energia. The Chinese company will make lend an additional $390 million to the Brazilian business. Galp Energia will retain the remaining 70 percent of Petrogal Brasil. The deal values the company’s Brazilian assets at $12.5 billion. China’s energy companies have spent billions of dollars in recent years to gain access to new energy resources. In October, Sinopec agreed to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and natural gas producer, for about $2.1 billion. The Chinese company also paid $7.1 billion last year for a 40 percent stake in the Brazilian assets of the Spanish energy firm Repsol YPF.
